channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Thunderbirds will fly over Southern California honoring coronavirus workers
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Luke Money
item.description: California workers on the front lines of the coronavirus fight will be honored from the sky during two military salutes this week.
item.content:encoded: California workers on the front lines of the coronavirus fight will be honored from the sky during two military salutes this week.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH,CA--October 19, 2018: The USAF Thunderbirds take a practice run in the skies over Huntington Beach for the 3rd Annual Great Pacific Airshow Friday October 19, 2018. The practice day drew thousands of spectators lining the sands to see stunt planes belching smoke and the USAF Thunderbirds flying over a large swath of Huntington Beach along the coast from Seapoint to Beach Boulevard Mark Boster/For The Los Angeles Times

item.title: CSU cancels fall in-person classes: What you need to know
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal, Teresa Watanabe
item.description: CSU cancels fall in-person classes: What you need to know
item.content:encoded: CSU cancels fall in-person classes: What you need to know

media:content.media:description: Long Beach, CA., March 11, 2020 - A student bikes pass The Walter Pyramid at Cal State Long Beach, where the campus has gone to online only classes on Tuesday, March 11, 2020 in Long Beach, California. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: The two big reasons why California struggles to control coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money, Alex Wigglesworth, Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Health officials say the coronavirus crisis persists because some people must still go out and because others are fed up with the stay-at-home orders.
item.content:encoded: Health officials say the coronavirus crisis persists because some people must still go out and because others are fed up with the stay-at-home orders.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CA - MAY 11, 2020 - - Bikers, against a backdrop of the Queen Mary, make their way along pedestrian and beach bike path on the first day that Long Beach reopened the path on Monday May 11, 2020. The city of Long Beach eased a few of its public health restrictions, allowing under certain guidelines the reopening of pedestrian and beach bike paths, tennis centers and courts. Beach bathrooms are also reopening, but the parking lots and beaches still remain closed. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Reopening restaurants, malls will be slower in some parts of California than others
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy, Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby
item.description: Only counties that meet state standards for testing and reducing coronavirus cases may allow dining in restaurants and and shopping in person.
item.content:encoded: Only counties that meet state standards for testing and reducing coronavirus cases may allow dining in restaurants and and shopping in person.

media:content.media:description: YUBA CITY, CA -- MAY 06: Customers wait in line on a first come first serve basis to have body piercings at Heart & Soul Tattoo on Wednesday, May 6, 2020, in Yuba City, CA. Every 30 minutes Wagner must stop and desensitize the table. The shop closes at 3 P.M. for an hour to sanitize the space. Sutter and Yuba counties, both north of Sacramento, are allowing businesses and restaurants to reopen, defying Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus pandemic. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD community policing has prevented crime and made residents feel safer, study finds
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: A UCLA study compared outcomes in two Watts housing projects where community policing was practiced with similar areas where it wasn't.
item.content:encoded: A UCLA study compared outcomes in two Watts housing projects where community policing was practiced with similar areas where it wasn't.

media:content.media:description: Eric Romero, 30, right, a resident at the Imperial Courts Housing Development in Watts, chats with Los Angeles police officers Delano Hutchins, left, and Angelo Marzan on July 30, 2015. The officers are members of the LAPD's Community Safety Partnership program.

item.title: Los Angeles County beaches reopen in a coronavirus milestone
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson, Colleen Shalby, Sarah Parvini
item.description: After a six-week closure, Los Angeles County beaches are reopening Wednesday for limited, active recreational use. Swimming is fine; sunbathing isn't.
item.content:encoded: After a six-week closure, Los Angeles County beaches are reopening Wednesday for limited, active recreational use. Swimming is fine; sunbathing isn't.

media:content.media:description: HERMOSA BEACH, CA - MAY 13: Three surfers came out to Hermosa Beach, CA, as Los Angeles County beaches re-open Wednesday, May 13, 2020, during the coronavirus pandemic. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Coronavirus is stalling air quality, pollution rules, even in eco-minded California
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza
item.description: Powerful industries are pressuring California regulators to delay or roll back air quality and climate regulations due the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Powerful industries are pressuring California regulators to delay or roll back air quality and climate regulations due the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: WILMINGTON, CA -- TUESDAY, MARCH 1, 2016 -- The Phillips 66 refinery looms over a Wilmington neighborhood where some long-time residents feel their health issues might stem from their proximity to the refinery. The Union Oil Company of California built the original refinery in 1919 between the old Anaheim road and the port, years before homes were constructed to form the neighborhood. ( Rick Loomis / Los Angeles Times )

item.title: S. David Freeman, public power chief and energy advisor, dies at 94
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: S. David Freeman, who steered the nation's largest public electric utilities with a commanding and at times uncompromising vision, dies at 94.
item.content:encoded: S. David Freeman, who steered the nation's largest public electric utilities with a commanding and at times uncompromising vision, dies at 94.

media:content.media:description: L.A. LEADERS: Geraldine Knatz, left, the L.A. port's executive director, and S. David Freeman, L.A. harbor commission president.

item.title: Most California voters say coronavirus is increasing inequality, especially among blacks, poll finds
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: Some 70% of California voters believe that the COVID-19 pandemic is increasing inequality in the United States, according to a UC Berkeley IGS poll. Most also agreed that there were racial disparities in the virus' effect.
item.content:encoded: Some 70% of California voters believe that the COVID-19 pandemic is increasing inequality in the United States, according to a UC Berkeley IGS poll. Most also agreed that there were racial disparities in the virus' effect.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-APRIL 8, 2020: A portrait and quote by Martin Luther King, Jr. overlooks a new mobile testing site for people with symptoms of the coronavirus at Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science in South Los Angeles on Wednesday, April 8, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: They're trapped, and the killer virus knows where to find them in California
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: COVID-19 doesn't play fair. It goes after the institutionalized, the poor and the elderly.
item.content:encoded: COVID-19 doesn't play fair. It goes after the institutionalized, the poor and the elderly.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO, CA -- TUESDAY, MAY 12, 2020: Rep. Nanette Diaz Barragan speaks during a press conference after touring the Federal Correctional Institute Terminal Island site to inquire about the ``extremely high'' number of COVID-19 cases among inmates and prison staff and about the steps being taken to address them. Photo taken outside the Federal Correctional Institute Terminal Island gate in San Pedro, CA, on May 12, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: A patient's return to hospital COVID-19 unit underscores uncertainty to come
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: Janice Brown was the first patient at Desert Valley Hospital's COVID-19 unit. And the first to be released. Neither she nor her doctors or nurses expected her to return. Within weeks, she tested positive again.
item.content:encoded: Janice Brown was the first patient at Desert Valley Hospital's COVID-19 unit. And the first to be released. Neither she nor her doctors or nurses expected her to return. Within weeks, she tested positive again.

media:content.media:description: VICTORVILLE, CA - APRIL 29: Janice Brown, left, grimaces, as dialysis nurse Jennifer Stolpp pokes her arm for dialysis at Desert Valley Medical Group. Victorville, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Republican Mike Garcia leads in race to fill Democrat Katie Hill's seat
item.dc:creator: Arit John
item.description: California Republicans haven't won control of a Democratic-held congressional seat since 1998.
item.content:encoded: California Republicans haven't won control of a Democratic-held congressional seat since 1998.

media:content.media:description: Republican Mike Garcia and Democrat Christy Smith are locked in a congressional race that both sides rate a toss-up.

item.title: After seventh coronavirus death at Terminal Island, congresswoman says inmates lack protection
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: After a seventh inmate at the Terminal Island federal prison died, a U.S. congresswoman visited and said detainees were desperate for protective equipment.
item.content:encoded: After a seventh inmate at the Terminal Island federal prison died, a U.S. congresswoman visited and said detainees were desperate for protective equipment.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO, CA -- TUESDAY, MAY 12, 2020: Rep. Nanette Diaz Barragan puts a mask on that she was given while speaking during a press conference after touring the Federal Correctional Institute Terminal Island site to inquire about the ``extremely high'' number of COVID-19 cases among inmates and prison staff and about the steps being taken to address them. Photo taken outside the Federal Correctional Institute Terminal Island gate in San Pedro, CA, on May 12, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 60 businesses charged with violating stay-at-home rules
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The owners of 60 businesses across L.A. are now facing criminal charges for violating Mayor Garcetti's stay-at-home order.

item.title: New signs that coronavirus restrictions are here for the long haul in California
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy, Colleen Shalby, Nina Agrawal
item.description: Even as officials laid out more tentative plans to reopen California's battered economy, there were growing signs Tuesday that life would not be getting back to normal any time soon.
item.content:encoded: Even as officials laid out more tentative plans to reopen California's battered economy, there were growing signs Tuesday that life would not be getting back to normal any time soon.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - MAY 12: Kim Abt, left, and Rachel Portugal walk the beach after a social media workout Tuesday morning on the sand in Santa Monica as Los Angeles County Beaches will reopen tomorrow for active use only due to the coronavirus pandemic. Parking lots, piers and boardwalks will remain closed. Beach on Tuesday, May 12, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Man whose wife and daughter died in crash that killed Kobe Bryant sues helicopter owner
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Christopher Chester, whose wife and daughter died in the helicopter crash that killed Kobe Bryant, has sued the company that operated the helicopter and the estate of the deceased pilot.
item.content:encoded: Christopher Chester, whose wife and daughter died in the helicopter crash that killed Kobe Bryant, has sued the company that operated the helicopter and the estate of the deceased pilot.

item.content:encoded: Silicon Valley has no immediate plans to weaken coronavirus stay-at-home order

media:content.media:description: Santa Clara County Public Health Department Director Dr. Sara Cody speaks during a news conference in San Jose, Calif., on Friday, Feb. 28, 2020. Santa Clara County health officials confirmed a second case of unknown origin of the novel coronavirus. (Anda Chu/Bay Area News Group via AP)

item.title: Orange County will unveil proposed coronavirus 'reopening' guidelines this week
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Orange County supervisors, and dozens of residents who turned out to lobby them Tuesday, are increasingly itching to relax restrictions that were imposed in response to the coronavirus outbreak and reopen businesses and public spaces.
item.content:encoded: Orange County supervisors, and dozens of residents who turned out to lobby them Tuesday, are increasingly itching to relax restrictions that were imposed in response to the coronavirus outbreak and reopen businesses and public spaces.

media:content.media:description: ORANGE COUNTY, CA - MAY 11: People walk at Seal Beach on Monday, May 11, 2020 in Orange County, CA. Seal Beach reopened to active use on Monday and will only be open during daylight hours Monday through Thursday. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD shootings hit 30-year low in 2019; less-lethal force has increased
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Fatal shootings by L.A. police officers declined for the fourth year in a row, according to a new report on police use of force.
item.content:encoded: Fatal shootings by L.A. police officers declined for the fourth year in a row, according to a new report on police use of force.

media:content.media:description: LAPD officers at a protest near City Hall on Tuesday, July 12.

item.title: Newsom sets new rules for reopening California restaurants, malls and offices amid coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Two months after Gov. Gavin Newsom's stay-at home order began, restaurants can reopen in counties meeting standards tied to the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: Two months after Gov. Gavin Newsom's stay-at home order began, restaurants can reopen in counties meeting standards tied to the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2019-2020 state budget during a news conference Thursday, May 9, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat, has proposed a $213.5 billion a spending plan. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: She organized California's back-to-work protests, but now she's calling it quits
item.dc:creator: Joshua Emerson Smith
item.description: Anti-lockdown protests have erupted all over California. Now, an organizer of the protests, under scrutiny from the media, is bowing out.
item.content:encoded: Anti-lockdown protests have erupted all over California. Now, an organizer of the protests, under scrutiny from the media, is bowing out.

media:content.media:description: Hundreds of protesters gathered in downtown San Diego to demand that California reopen on May 1, 2020 in San Diego, California.
media:content.media:credit: Joshua Emerson Smith / The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: CSU plans to cancel most in-person classes and go online this fall, chancellor says
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: CSU plans to cancel most in-person classes this fall and rely mainly on virtual instruction amid the coronavirus crisis, the chancellor announced Tuesday.
item.content:encoded: CSU plans to cancel most in-person classes this fall and rely mainly on virtual instruction amid the coronavirus crisis, the chancellor announced Tuesday.

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON-CA-APRIL 21, 2020: Cal State University Fullerton student Linh Trinh, 21, right, and her boyfriend Tan Nguyen, 21, walk around a deserted CSUF campus on Tuesday, April 21, 2020. The school is planning to begin Fall semester with online classes, one of the first universities in the nation to make that move as campuses throughout the country grapple with how long to stay closed to most students amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County coronavirus cases: Here are the latest numbers by community
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The number of coronavirus infections continues to rise in Orange County. Here's the latest city-by-city data.
item.content:encoded: The number of coronavirus infections continues to rise in Orange County. Here's the latest city-by-city data.

media:content.media:description: ORANGE COUNTY, CA - MAY 11: Shawn Jones, Yari Perkins, Kalani Delarole and Keira Toor, left to right, play spikeball at Seal Beach on Monday, May 11, 2020 in Orange County, CA. Seal Beach reopened to active use on Monday and will only be open during daylight hours Monday through Thursday. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD releases body-camera video of beating of homeless Boyle Heights man

item.description: The LAPD released body camera video taken during a violent clash between an officer and a homeless man in Boyle Heights last month.
item.content:encoded: The LAPD released body camera video taken during a violent clash between an officer and a homeless man in Boyle Heights last month.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- MONDAY, JANUARY 28, 2019: LAPD Chief Michel Moore announces that for the first time in five years, violent crime was down in Los Angeles in 2018, with the number of homicides on track to be among the lowest in more than 50 years during a press conference at LAPD headquarters in Los Angeles, Calif., on Jan. 28, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. County could keep stay-at-home orders in place well into summer, depending on conditions
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Sarah Parvini
item.description: Los Angeles County's stay-at-home orders will 'with all certainty' be extended for the next three months, Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer said.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County's stay-at-home orders will 'with all certainty' be extended for the next three months, Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer said.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 11: The flight crew for a Hainan Airlines flight walk through the Tom Bradley International Terminal, Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) which is now requiring travelers to wear face covering to help keep fellow passengers and crew safe by limiting the spread of the coronavirus Covid-19. The new requirements for wearing face masks in Los Angels began Monday at LAX and on local public transit. LAX on Monday, May 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 3.3 quake strikes near Imperial, Calif.

item.title: Riverside County sees rise in coronavirus cases after vote to rescind local public health orders
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: Following a vote Friday to rescind Riverside County's local public health orders, officials on Monday reported 150 new coronavirus cases and 12 deaths.
item.content:encoded: Following a vote Friday to rescind Riverside County's local public health orders, officials on Monday reported 150 new coronavirus cases and 12 deaths.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CALIFORNIA - MAY 8, 2020: Residents who want public health orders rescinded wait to enter the County Adminstrative Center to speak during the public comment time of an emergency Riverside County Board of Supervisors meeting in the midst of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic on May 8, 2020 in Riverside, California. (Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fauci cautious about schools, colleges reopening in fall: 'We better be careful"
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Noam N. Levey
item.description: Anthony Fauci says the reopening of academic institutions in the fall will largely depend on the ability to do widespread testing and other factors.
item.content:encoded: Anthony Fauci says the reopening of academic institutions in the fall will largely depend on the ability to do widespread testing and other factors.

media:content.media:description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, announced Thursday that the "Mississippi Baby" thought to have been functionally cured of HIV now has detectable levels of the virus in her blood.

item.title: Air National Guard to crisscross California to salute essential coronavirus workers
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: A sky-high salute will honor California's workers on the front lines in the battle against the coronavirus on Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: A sky-high salute will honor California's workers on the front lines in the battle against the coronavirus on Wednesday.

media:content.media:description: Crowds gather around a static display of an F-15C fighter jet Eagle from the 144th Fighter Wing during the 2017 Open House held Oct. 14, 2017 at Fresno Air National Guard Base, California. Thousands of people from the local communities attended the 2017 Open House to learn more about the mission of the 144th FW. (U.S. Air National Guard Photo by Staff Sgt. Christian Jadot)
media:content.media:credit: Staff Sgt. Christian Jadot / 144th Fighter Wing

item.title: Scores of L.A. businesses reopened but failed to follow safety rules, officials say
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Maura Dolan
item.description: L.A. County health officials surveyed 410 newly reopened businesses over the weekend and found 162 failed to follow social distancing guidelines.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County health officials surveyed 410 newly reopened businesses over the weekend and found 162 failed to follow social distancing guidelines.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES , CALIF. - MAY 8, 2020. A customer picks up a purchase at the front door of a sports shoe and apparel store along Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles on Friday, May 8. 2020. As coronavirus restrictions are loosened, retail shops are allowed to reopen if they provide curbside pickup and practice social distanciong. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Gimme Shelter podcast: What's behind those California rent strikes over coronavirus?
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon
item.description: Weeks into the coronavirus pandemic, some tenants in California have turned their economic hardship into a political protest, demanding an end to rent.
item.content:encoded: Weeks into the coronavirus pandemic, some tenants in California have turned their economic hardship into a political protest, demanding an end to rent.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - APR. 30, 2020. Tenants and their supporters from across Los Angeles gather at city hall on Thursday, Apr. 30, 2020, to call on L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti, the L.A. City Council, and California Gov. Gavin Newsom to cancel rent and mortgage payments during the COVID-19 crisis. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Slammed economically by the coronavirus, Santa Monica offers grim preview of crisis to come
item.dc:creator: Joe Mozingo
item.description: Los Angeles County has 88 cities. A reformer says that in the face of the pandemic's economic impact, cities will have to transform or wither.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County has 88 cities. A reformer says that in the face of the pandemic's economic impact, cities will have to transform or wither.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CALIF. - MAY 8, 2020. Santa Monica Place and the Third Street Promenade in Santa Monica are largely deserted on Friday, May 8. 2020. As coronavirus restrictions are loosened, retail shops are allowed to reopen if they provide curbside pickup and practice social distancing. However, most shops in downtown Santa Monica remained closed on Friday. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: From botox clinics to wellness spas, antibody tests become the rage. Are they the real thing?

item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: Experts warn of misplaced trust in antibody tests

(Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: People want beef. Ranchers have cows. Here's what's going wrong

item.title: As coronavirus deaths mount, California still very much in danger zone
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Iris Lee, Colleen Shalby
item.description: Mirroring a trend seen nationally, California has not seen a dramatic and sustained decline in deaths over the past month, a Los Angeles Times analysis has found.
item.content:encoded: Mirroring a trend seen nationally, California has not seen a dramatic and sustained decline in deaths over the past month, a Los Angeles Times analysis has found.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CA - MAY 11, 2020 - - Scially distanced bikers and walkers, against a backdrop of the Queen Mary, make their way along pedestrian and beach bike path on the first day that Long Beach reopened the path on Monday May 11, 2020. The city of Long Beach eased a few of its public health restrictions, allowing under certain guidelines the reopening of pedestrian and beach bike paths, tennis centers and courts. Beach bathrooms are also reopening, but the parking lots and beaches still remain closed. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California considers unprecedented $25-billion economy recovery fund, rental relief
item.dc:creator: John Myers

item.content:encoded: Two unprecedented proposals to help Californians weather the fiscal storm unleashed by the coronavirus crisis are expected to be unveiled Tuesday by Democrats in the state Senate.

(Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Rodeo in Shasta County delays plans to reopen as many fans sidestep coronavirus guidelines
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A day after crowds flocked to a rodeo, Shasta County said Monday that rodeogoers — many of whom showed up without masks or keeping a safe distance from one another — have delayed the county's plans to reopen under COVID-19 rules.
item.content:encoded: A day after crowds flocked to a rodeo, Shasta County said Monday that rodeogoers — many of whom showed up without masks or keeping a safe distance from one another — have delayed the county's plans to reopen under COVID-19 rules.

item.title: Despite partial reopening of beaches, Huntington Beach presses for injunction on state order
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Huntington Beach is pressing ahead for an injunction against Gov. Gavin Newsom's decision last month to close the city's beaches due to the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Huntington Beach is pressing ahead for an injunction against Gov. Gavin Newsom's decision last month to close the city's beaches due to the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- MONDAY, MAY 11, 2020: Some beach-goers actively use the beach while others relax on the beach, despite Gov. Newsom's active-use-only allowance at the beach in Huntington Beach, CA, on May 11, 2020. The city of Huntington Beach is still pursuing their lawsuit against the state to reopen the beach to all forms of activities - including sun bathing.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: YouTube star Corey La Barrie dies after L.A. car crash on his 25th birthday; suspect arrested
item.dc:creator: Tracy Brown , Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Corey La Barrie, who amassed more than 340,000 followers on YouTube, died Sunday in Los Angeles after a car crash on his 25th birthday. On Monday, Daniel Joseph Silva, a celebrity tattoo artist, was arrested on suspicion of murder.
item.content:encoded: Corey La Barrie, who amassed more than 340,000 followers on YouTube, died Sunday in Los Angeles after a car crash on his 25th birthday. On Monday, Daniel Joseph Silva, a celebrity tattoo artist, was arrested on suspicion of murder.

item.title: Avoid weekend trips and summer vacations for now, California health officials say
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby, Maura Dolan
item.description: Avoid planning weekend trips and summer vacations for now, California health officials say
item.content:encoded: Avoid planning weekend trips and summer vacations for now, California health officials say

item.title: Los Angeles County beaches may reopen Wednesday. Here are the new rules
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: LA County beaches should reopen Wednesday with some restrictions on activities and other rules in place, officials said Monday.
item.content:encoded: LA County beaches should reopen Wednesday with some restrictions on activities and other rules in place, officials said Monday.

item.title: Coronavirus cases continue to climb in Orange County
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: There are a number of reasons why Orange County continues to see new coronavirus infections, but there's no evidence that the throngs of people who flocked to the region's famed shoreline weeks ago have contributed to the caseload, officials said Monday.
item.content:encoded: There are a number of reasons why Orange County continues to see new coronavirus infections, but there's no evidence that the throngs of people who flocked to the region's famed shoreline weeks ago have contributed to the caseload, officials said Monday.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- MONDAY, MAY 11, 2020: Some beach-goers actively use the beach while others relax on the beach, despite Gov. Newsom's active-use-only allowance at the beach in Huntington Beach, CA, on May 11, 2020. The city of Huntington Beach is still pursuing their lawsuit against the state to reopen the beach to all forms of activities - including sun bathing.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Civil rights leaders want charges against LAPD officer in beating video; Lacey asks for patience
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Civil rights leaders called for criminal charges to be filed against an LAPD officer shown beating a man in the head in a recent viral video.
item.content:encoded: Civil rights leaders called for criminal charges to be filed against an LAPD officer shown beating a man in the head in a recent viral video.

media:content.media:description: Dist. Atty. Jackie Lacey is working with a group of leaders from different agencies to expand diversion programs for mentally ill criminal defendants.

item.title: 134 pregnant women in L.A. tested positive for coronavirus, but none of their babies
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: More than 130 pregnant women in L.A. had coronavirus, but none of their babies
item.content:encoded: More than 130 pregnant women in L.A. had coronavirus, but none of their babies

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: SAT should be suspended for UC admissions, Napolitano says
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: UC president recommends suspending the SAT and ACT as admissions requirements, proposing instead a plan to make them optional for two years.
item.content:encoded: UC president recommends suspending the SAT and ACT as admissions requirements, proposing instead a plan to make them optional for two years.

media:content.media:description: UC President Janet Napolitano speaks during a hearing of the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee in Washington on July 29.

item.title: Newsom joins 4 governors in seeking $1 trillion in federal relief for all states
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom and his counterparts in four Western states have asked Congress for $1 trillion in pandemic relief for all states.
item.content:encoded: California Gov. Gavin Newsom and his counterparts in four Western states have asked Congress for $1 trillion in pandemic relief for all states.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif., Tuesday, April 14, 2020. Newsom said he won't loosen the state's mandatory stay-at-home order until hospitalizations, particularly those in intensive care units, "flatten and start to decline." (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.content:encoded: Experts attribute a rising forecast of coronavirus-linked deaths to the public growing more weary of stay-at-home orders and moves to roll them back.

Pressure grows in California to ease stay-at-home restrictions while around the world COVID-19 has spread claiming over 248,000 lives with over 3.5 million cases. (Photo by Rich Fury/Getty Images)

item.content:encoded: Like its neighbors farther south, Seal Beach has restored access to its shores for active use — walking, running, swimming, surfing and other 'in-motion' activities.

Seal Beach reopened to active use on Monday and will only be open during daylight hours Monday through Thursday. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Testing students for coronavirus in the fall is a big unanswered question

item.content:encoded: Other major concerns facing L.A. Unified include supplying masks for students and staff, and sanitizing schools, schools Supt. Austin Beutner says.

media:content.media:description: SAN FERNANDO, CA-APRIL 20, 2020: LAUSD Superintendant Austin Beutner, right, wearing a protective mask against the coronavirus, helps distribute food while touring one of the district't Grab & Go food centers at San Fernando Senior High School, where meals were given out to LAUSD students in need. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 8 photos from Santa Cruz during the coronavirus pandemic
item.dc:creator: Gary Coronado , Marc Martin
item.description: Photos: The ocean remains open for water sports in Santa Cruz, but passive activities at beaches are prohibited amid the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Photos: The ocean remains open for water sports in Santa Cruz, but passive activities at beaches are prohibited amid the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: SANTA CRUZ, CA -- MAY 08: The Beach Boardwalk is closed to guests as a couple walks along an empty Main Beach on Friday, May 8, 2020, in Santa Cruz, CA. As the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases in Santa Cruz County continue to rise the City of Santa Cruz is taking necessary precautionary efforts to contain the spread of this virus and mitigate its impact. City of Santa Cruz beaches will be closed from 11:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., daily until further notice. The ocean will remain open for water sports (e.g., surfing, boogie-boarding, swimming, paddle-boarding, kayaking, boating, etc.), and individuals may cross beaches in order to access and leave the ocean. All other non-exercise, passive, or sedentary activities at beaches, such as sitting, lying, standing, picnicking, etc, are prohibited. Please continue to observe safe distancing while at our beaches. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Rebellion in Inland Empire over masks: 'I'm not afraid. ... People get old and they die'
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: Riverside County officials voted unanimously to rescind all stay-at-home orders that went beyond Gov. Newsom's, including a face mask requirement.
item.content:encoded: Riverside County officials voted unanimously to rescind all stay-at-home orders that went beyond Gov. Newsom's, including a face mask requirement.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CALIFORNIA - MAY 8, 2020: Residents who want public health orders rescinded cheer during the public forum section of an emergency meeting of the Riverside County Board of Supervisors at the County Administrative Center in the midst of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic on May 8, 2020 in Riverside, California. Type written notes are placed on chairs to keep people from sitting near each other. (Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times)

Community members nominated other community members to be recipients of 150 free food and essential item bags and gift cards to 99cents Only Store and Target. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Arts center in Gold Rush town opens, but coronavirus forces closure two days later. What now?
item.dc:creator: Anh Do
item.description: After a multimillion-dollar makeover, an arts center in tiny, ravaged Grass Valley opened. But the coronavirus forced its closure in the Gold Rush town two days later. What now?
item.content:encoded: After a multimillion-dollar makeover, an arts center in tiny, ravaged Grass Valley opened. But the coronavirus forced its closure in the Gold Rush town two days later. What now?

media:content.media:description: Interior photo of the $6 million The Center for the Arts in Grass Valley. Grass Valley, with a population of about 13,000, is located in Nevada County, home to almost 100,000. Before the center's multi-million renovation, the nearest arts venue was a 60-mile drive to Sacramento.

item.title: L.A. animal shelters brace for influx of pets as people face financial hardships from coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: Although fosters are way up during the coronavirus crisis, L.A. Animal Services officials worry that growing financial hardships will force more people to surrender their pets at city shelters.
item.content:encoded: Although fosters are way up during the coronavirus crisis, L.A. Animal Services officials worry that growing financial hardships will force more people to surrender their pets at city shelters.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 07: Paulina Valdivia and her father Carlos Stouffer both of Los Angeles bring a litter of stray kittens found near their home to the South Los Angeles Animal Shelter during the coronavirus pandemic on Thursday, May 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. The coronavirus pandemic is hitting the Animal Services Department hard. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Stir-crazy Californians are crowding Arizona's Lake Havasu
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: As much of California closed down its beaches in the face of the deadly COVID-19 pandemic, Golden Staters looking for freedom and respite from the heat have flocked to Lake Havasu.
item.content:encoded: As much of California closed down its beaches in the face of the deadly COVID-19 pandemic, Golden Staters looking for freedom and respite from the heat have flocked to Lake Havasu.

media:content.media:description: LAKE HAVASU, ARIZONA MAY 9, 2020-Boats pass through a chanel during a hot day in Lake Havasu City, Arizona. The city has been crowded by an influx of Californians over the past few weekends as residents are concerned about the cornavirus spreading but also want the economy open. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's coronavirus outlook worse than researchers expected, as cases and deaths rise

County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

Gavin Newsom speaking at a news briefing at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. California will help skilled nursing facilities wracked by the new virus by providing additional bed space for their patients on a Navy hospital ship and shipping masks and gloves for their workers, the governor said Friday, April 10. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

Jay Hom, helps assemble kits consisting of an N95 mask, work gloves, and nitrile gloves, as he and other LAPD personnel assemble personal safety kits for field officers to protect themselves from exposure to the Coronavirus, at Piper Technical Center on Wednesday, March 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. item.title: Bagpiper's nightly coronavirus serenade sounds a mournful yet hopeful note in Santa Monica park
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: A bagpiper appears nightly at sunset in Santa Monica's Palisades Park to play "Amazing Grace," a pandemic ritual both mournful and hopeful.
item.content:encoded: A bagpiper appears nightly at sunset in Santa Monica's Palisades Park to play "Amazing Grace," a pandemic ritual both mournful and hopeful.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - MAY 01: Andrew McGregor poses at the corner of San Vicente Blvd and Ocean Avenue, on his way to Palisades Park to perform "Amazing Grace" on his bagpipes at sunset, in Santa Monica, CA, Friday, May 1, 2020, during the coronavirus pandemic. Playing the bagpipes for about two years, McGregor has been performing at sunset since around mid-March, with a small number of people gathering nearby to watch and listen. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Los Angeles Times

item.title: During the pandemic, Republicans see a rare political opportunity in California

item.title: Desert mystery: Why have pronghorn antelope returned to Death Valley?
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun
item.description: Desert naturalists are unsure why pronghorn antelope have returned to one of the hottest places on earth. Will they be in a pickle this summer?
item.content:encoded: Desert naturalists are unsure why pronghorn antelope have returned to one of the hottest places on earth. Will they be in a pickle this summer?

media:content.media:description: BEATTY, NV - MAY 06: A pronghorn antelope pauses while eating wildflowers along a highway where cattle once grazed near the Mojave Desert town of Beatty, NV. on Wednesday, May 6, 2020. "Pronghorn are following lush buffets of rain-fed wildflowers," said California director of the nonprofit Western Watersheds Project Laura Cunningham. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 'We want to study you.' For black Angelenos, coronavirus triggers fear of another Tuskegee
item.dc:creator: Angel Jennings
item.description: With black Americans getting the coronavirus at high rates, officials are fighting a legacy of mistrust of doctors going back to the Tuskegee Experiment.
item.content:encoded: With black Americans getting the coronavirus at high rates, officials are fighting a legacy of mistrust of doctors going back to the Tuskegee Experiment.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MAY 7, 2020: Jacquelyn Temple, 72, is photographed outside her home in Leimert Park on Thursday, May 7, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Small towns across the Sierra fear tourists will bring coronavirus with them
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove, Sarah Parvini
item.description: The Sierra Nevada towns that dot Alpine County have no hospital. Nor do they have a single doctor's office or clinic.
item.content:encoded: The Sierra Nevada towns that dot Alpine County have no hospital. Nor do they have a single doctor's office or clinic.

media:content.media:description: MARIPOSA, CA - APRIL 29, 2020 - - A pair of wooden bear sculptures seem to guard a closed Grizzly Mini Mart and Gas Station along Highway 140 in the heart of Mariposa on April 29, 2020. The gas station is one of the few businesses that is still open during the day in Mariposa. Most of the storefronts have been closed since Gov. Gavin Newsom announced in mid-March that all Californians were being required to shelter in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. Mariposa County is one of five California counties that as of April 28 only had one reported coronavirus case, despite the fact all the surroundings have. A 23-year-old woman in Marioposa County had tested positive for COVID-190. More than 47,000 Californians have tested positive for the novel coronavirus but in Mariposa County, Tuesday's result was the first. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: In the coronavirus crisis, Newsom uses social media to raise awareness of the pandemic — and his profile
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Jennifer Lu, Sara Stoudt
item.description: The first California governor to fully embrace social media while in office and unleash it as an extension of the bully pulpit, Newsom has capitalized on viral moments, enlisting celebrities as his surrogates to persuade the state's residents to abide by his stay-at-home order amid the coronavirus crisis and touting his frequent television appearances to discuss the pandemic on Facebook and Twitter.
item.content:encoded: The first California governor to fully embrace social media while in office and unleash it as an extension of the bully pulpit, Newsom has capitalized on viral moments, enlisting celebrities as his surrogates to persuade the state's residents to abide by his stay-at-home order amid the coronavirus crisis and touting his frequent television appearances to discuss the pandemic on Facebook and Twitter.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif., Tuesday, April 14, 2020. Newsom said he won't loosen the state's mandatory stay-at-home order until hospitalizations, particularly those in intensive care units, "flatten and start to decline."(AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: Column One: Clean up on aisle everywhere – a day in the life of supermarket workers during coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: For the last few months, grocery stores have served as public theaters for the traumatized American consumer.
item.content:encoded: For the last few months, grocery stores have served as public theaters for the traumatized American consumer.

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE, CA - APRIL 27: Ping Moyer, right, working for Vons alongside Michael Mason who works for Orowheat as they stock shelves at the Vons located at 24325 Crenshaw Blvd in Torrance before doors open at 6 a.m. for seniors and at-risk shoppers due to the Coronavirus. Most of the team arrives at 5 a.m. to stock the shelves with product, sanitize the location for staff and shoppers, and picker/shoppers begin to collect items for .com home delivery shoppers. Vendors arriving throughout the morning must read a checklist of warnings, sign in and they must wear face covering. Vons on Monday, April 27, 2020 in Torrance, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Surfer dies after shark attack off Santa Cruz County coast
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: The 26-year-old surfer was pronounced dead at the scene near Manresa State Beach, California parks officials said.
item.content:encoded: The 26-year-old surfer was pronounced dead at the scene near Manresa State Beach, California parks officials said.

media:content.media:description: Undated photo of Maresa State Beach which is a state-protected beach on Monterey Bay near Watsonville in Santa Cruz County, California.
media:content.media:credit: California Department of Parks and Recreation

item.title: Rain likely in Northern California as late-season system arrives from the Pacific
item.dc:creator: Paul Duginski
item.description: A low-pressure trough pushing into Northern California from the Pacific will bring widespread showers to the part of the state most in need of rain.
item.content:encoded: A low-pressure trough pushing into Northern California from the Pacific will bring widespread showers to the part of the state most in need of rain.

media:content.media:description: Showers are likely across Northern California Monday night and Tuesday.

item.title: Protesters gather outside Mayor Garcetti's Hancock Park residence to protest health restrictions
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: At least 100 protesters gathered outside the residence of Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti, with marchers calling for the economy to reopen and condemning the health orders enacted in response to the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: At least 100 protesters gathered outside the residence of Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti, with marchers calling for the economy to reopen and condemning the health orders enacted in response to the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Mayor Eric Garcetti, shown at City Hall last year, met with Obama administration officials met local nonprofits and business owners to discuss ways to encourage immigrants to become U.S. citizens.

item.title: As more Southern California beaches and parks reopen, it's 'like being set free'
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun, Kevin Baxter, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Coronavirus reopening: more beaches and parks
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus reopening: more beaches and parks

media:content.media:description: WOODLAND HILLS, CA - MAY 09: A mountain biker wearing a mask at Upper Las Virgenes Canyon Open Space Preserve takes advantage of newly reopened trails Saturday, May 9, 2020 in Woodland Hills, CA. Masks were mandatory but only around half of the people were wearing them. A park ranger was warning people to wear their masks, yet another park ranger who was ticketing nearby cars without permits, was not wearing one herself. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Grateful hikers return to Griffith Park: 'Like being set free'
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun
item.description: 'Like being set free:' Grateful hikers returning to Griffith Park
item.content:encoded: 'Like being set free:' Grateful hikers returning to Griffith Park

media:content.media:description: This unique trail located south of Griffith Park holds spectacular views of cities, bikers and hikers.
media:content.media:credit: Maria Alejandra Cardona / Los Angeles Times

item.title: As demand for food skyrockets due to coronavirus, food banks play catch-up
item.dc:creator: Esmeralda Bermudez
item.description: The need for food in L.A. County has reached record levels, putting food banks under pressure to deliver even while their normal supply chains are disrupted.
item.content:encoded: The need for food in L.A. County has reached record levels, putting food banks under pressure to deliver even while their normal supply chains are disrupted.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 06: Volunteer Nina Forbess gives baby food to a grateful Monica Alcazar in the vehicle with 19-year-old daughter Miriam Alcazar at St. Margaret's Center Catholic Charities of Los Angeles as close to 300 families line up now each Wednesday to collect food at a drive-thru and walk-up pantry. The need for food has reached record levels in L.A. County and food banks are hustling to keep up. The Los Angeles Regional Food Bank has gone from serving 300,000 families to to 500,00 families per month. Some are now having to purchase or compete for food as supplies are running slow or they are struggling with a shortage of volunteers. Downtown on Wednesday, May 6, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: One man's quest to document the Westside's homeless and hold officials accountable
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: Semi-retired in Westwood, he'd rather stay at home, but begins each day taking a homeless tent census.
item.content:encoded: Semi-retired in Westwood, he'd rather stay at home, but begins each day taking a homeless tent census.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 07: Don Wood observes a new growing homeless encampment outside the fences of the Los Angeles National Veterans Park as he follows a regular route touring homeless encampments on the Los Angeles Westside. Wearing a mask and practicing social distancing because of the Coronavirus Covid-19 there are about six encampment sites he checks every day. Westwood on Thursday, May 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County coronavirus-related deaths top 1,500
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials reported 1,011 new coronavirus cases and 44 related deaths Saturday.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials reported 1,011 new coronavirus cases and 44 related deaths Saturday.

media:content.media:description: WEST HILLS, CA - MAY 09: Hikers at El Scorpion Park take advantage of newly reopened trails on Saturday, May 9, 2020 in West Hills, CA. Masks were mandatory but only around half of the people out hiking and mountain biking were wearing them. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. County judges and other staff required to wear face masks in courts due to coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: All L.A. County Superior Court bench officers will be required to wear face coverings while on the bench or in courthouse public areas, the court said.
item.content:encoded: All L.A. County Superior Court bench officers will be required to wear face coverings while on the bench or in courthouse public areas, the court said.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 21: Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Miguel Espinoza holds arraignments in his courtroom via video at Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center on Tuesday, April 21, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Teen volunteers organize service to help most vulnerable during coronavirus outbreak
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: Volunteers from six Santa Clarita Valley high schools step forward to help those shut in by the COVID-19 pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Volunteers from six Santa Clarita Valley high schools step forward to help those shut in by the COVID-19 pandemic.

media:content.media:description: *DO NOT USE UNTIL KEVIN BAXTER STORY RUNS* VALENCIA, CA - MAY 05, 2020 - - Christine Riel, 16, left, and Krysta Mendoza, 17, juniors at West Ranch High School , fill an online grocery order from the site, sixfeetsupplies.com at an Albertson's store in Valencia on May 5, 2020. The students shop for homebound people, who are not just seniors, but anyone who needs help. The work is completely voluntary and the students are not paid. Six Feet Supplies, which takes its name from the separation required by social distancing, has more than 100 volunteers delivering food to a dozen homes a day, serving the homeless and manning a telephone help line for people who just need to talk. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)
